author: Andrew Charman
title: Frankfurt: Renault's Megane looks upmarket
text:
Frankfurt: Renault’s Megane looks upmarket Posted by Andrew Charman Date: September 16, 2015 in: New Car Renault’s all-new Megane, debuting at the Frankfurt show, has more premium rival models in its sights.
The French brand says that its core family hatch will be offered “loaded with technology features from higher-segment cars.”
On sale in the UK in summer 2016, the Megane will be offered with six engines topped by a GT model developed with the brand’s Renaultsport competition department.
According to Renault’s design head Laurens van den Acker the new Mégane plays an integral part in the brand’s design renewal strategy.
“Its dynamic lines project both sensuality and status, while its assertive proportions provide it with a well-planted stance on the road and its sculpted forms and strong shoulders hint at the brand’s Latin roots,” van den Acker says, also commenting on what he describes as “a distinctive lighting signature both front and rear, by day as well as by night”, and an interior with “an unmistakable cockpit feel.”
The car is built on the group’s Common Module Family (CMF) platform and compared to the previous third-generation model it is 64mm longer , 25mm lower with track widths front and rear widened by 47mm and 39mm respectively, and a 28mm longer wheelbase – according to Renault outstretching its rivals with consequent improvements in interior space. Boot capacity at 434 litres is beaten by only one rival.
At launch the Megane will be available with a six-strong engine range – diesel units of 89, 108 and 128bhp and petrol offerings of 99, 128 and 202bhp. A six-speed manual gearbox will be standard, an EDC dual-clutch auto offered on the 108 diesel and 128 petrol, while the 202bhp GT model gets a seven-speed EDC as standard.
The 108bhp dCi 110 diesel is expected to be the core Megane model, with combined cycle fuel economy of 85.6mpg and CO2 emissions of 86g/km.
Early in 2017 Renault intends to launch a hybrid version of the Megane, which with fuel economy stretching past 94mpg and emissions down to 76g/km is being pitched as the market leader for efficiency.
Renault also states that the Megane is introducing technology not previously typical of the sector. This includes a retractable colour head-up display, a customisable TFT (Thin Film Transistor) instrument display with in higher-spec models the option of a portrait-style 8.7-inch screen, and Renault’s Multi-Sense technology – a system activated by a button on the centre console that allows the driver to customize the car’s functions, modifying the accelerator pedal and engine response, adjusting the speed of the gearshifts in the automatic transmission and even controlling the massage function of the seats and the cabin lighting.
The top-line GT model will also include 4Control, a four-wheel-steer system that offers precise handling on challenging twisty roads and also improves manoeuvrability at slower speeds or when parking.
